Hi all,

A few, I hope, different thoughts about hyperNEAT in the checkers domain...

Did hyperNEAT _really_ discover the regularities of the board, or 
where they still encoded (or partly encoded) in the setup of the 
system?  I'll readily admit that if they were encoded then it was far 
less directly than in other AI approaches, but...

What I'm getting at is that the choice of coordinate space for the 
hidden layer (2D) and the choice of sampling pattern and interval 
(8x8 square grid) were supplied in the experimental setup...

I don't have a full fix for this, but what I'd like to see is 
experiments along the lines of (some of these overlap):

a) use hidden layers of differing size and dimensionality.  This may 
not degrade performance at all, in that there is no reason for the 
nodes in the hidden layer to be entirely geometric in their 
"meaning".  e.g. there may be a node in the hidden layer which means 
"number of my pieces in corner locations" -- the meaning may not be 
directly related to the area of the input layer corresponding to the 
node in the hidden layer...  I'd be inclined to try:

a1) 1d hidden layer of various lengths (akin to degrading to a 
non-hyper NEAT approach except you still have half the capability to 
exploit geometry, e.g. the CPPN can still exploit regularities in 
coordinates on the input layer)
a2) 3d hidden layer of similar volume to the original but different 
shapes, e.g. original was 8x8 = 64, 4x4x4 is a different shape but same size...
a3) high-dimensional but small hidden layer, such as 
2x2x2x2x2x2.  You may want to look to the types of function in the 
CPPN for this, e.g. because each ordinate on the hidden layer is 
binary, you may want binary operators in the CPPN

b) change the sample grid on the hidden layer:

b1) over sample x2, x3
b2) sample the 7x7 or 9x9 grids that correspond to the square corners 
on the input layer
b3) under sample by x2, x3
b4) offset each sample position in the hidden layer by a constant 
random vector (different for each sample but fixed for the 
experiment), vary the size 0.01, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5...

c) change the coordinate system.  I do wonder whether in defining the 
CPPN in terms of 2D coordinates (OK, 2x 2D) you have accidentally 
built in fore-knowledge of the geometry...  Try:

c1) input and hidden layers sampled at same points but using polar coordinates
c2) as previous but one polar and one Cartesian
c3) rotate the sample points in the hidden layer by: 90 degrees 
(should have no effect?), 45 degrees, or 10 degrees

I think experiments such as these would hammer down whether hyperNEAT 
is fully discovering the geometry, or whether it was gifted with a 
geometric system.  In the latter case it is still discovering 
regularities, but it is doing it within a geometric framework that it 
already knew.

Great experiment as it stands though!  And congratulations for 
getting it closer to the mainstream (not that we need them :-) ).

Just a quick question, were "kings" used in the rule base, e.g. when 
a piece reaches the back row it becomes a "king" and can move 
backwards...  If so I guess you used input values of greater 
magnitude for those?

Regards,

Ian
